title: Low attestations success rate
body:
Using latest released version 2.38.1, but it has been happening since months.

Attestations success is weak, my validator sits in the bottom 98% of all mainnet validators. No evident errors in the logs, it just stops being in sync.

```
Feb 08 16:53:11 localhost.localdomain nimbus_beacon_node[4154280]: INF 2023-02-08 16:53:11.016+00:00 Execution client not in sync; skipping validator duties for now
```

Last but not least, the server has a NVMe SSD with 4 CPUs and 1.15 load average, also 4GB free memory. Erigon is eating 8Gb of non shared anonymous memory.

Currently using Erigon v2.33.2 on mainnet, with Lighthouse v3.4.0, on an AWS EC2 instance (im4gn.xlarge) and my validators are performing as expected.  I will not say Erigon is an example of stability, but I still think your problem might not be only Erigon here.
What about network connectivity? Peer count? iostat?
not enough logs. do `| grep -v [p2p] | grep -v [txpool]`
peer count is enough I got more than 100 incoming + outgoing connections on port 30303, where should I look to start troubleshoot why Erigon is so insufferably worse than Geth
I have to restart it like 3 or 4 times a day so that it can progress, otherwise it keeps doing nothing and missing attestations. In testnet it runs fine tho
Start from showing logs https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/issues/6807#issuecomment-1423612181

“ It keeps printing a mix of [p2p] and [txpool] over and ” it means it doesn’t do anything.  So, need to find where it stuck… maybe you can do “pkill -SIGUSR1 erigon” if it stuck again

> Restarted and after 3 hours, back to doing nothing again. Machine is largely idle, `iostat` shows 80% idle, restarted the process and it started processing again. What is the version I should run that is stable?

It also possible that it doing pruning too long…  try increase logs verbosity.
thanks for the tips, will try them when it stops again

Also, I noticed a pattern: Erigon slowly keeps sucking memory, and when it piles up near 9GB of RAM (anonymous, non-shared memory, non-reusable by the OS) it starts to get behind and in extreme cases to stop working at all until restarting.
You never explicitly stated how much RAM your node has in total ? Also post a `top` please.

I have 32 Gb of RAM, but I run other things in the server. Server load average hovers around 1.5 - 2 for a quad-cpu server. CPU definitely is not a bottleneck. For a 32 Gb RAM server, Erigon taking 9Gb resident anon memory slice, during normal operation is a definitely a no-go. The reason I came to Erigon is because geth was using 4Gb and I wanted to reduce it

>  I run other things in the server.

I assumed that, that's why I wanted to see the top. With used, buffered, cached, free memory, the swap, and the other top RAM consumers of the node.
I'm no Erigon developer, but I operate an Erigon node for nearly 2 years now, and one thing I know is that Erigon is **very** reliant on his ability to use a huge amount of cached memory. It's not memory exclusively attributed to the process, from what I understand Erigon is massively using files opened through RAM buffer.  Technically, the OS manages that space and *will* reduce its allocation when needed, but then Erigon will start slowing down, and down, and down.
As an example, my production node has 16GB RAM, only 7GB is used (mostly by Erigon) but **more than 8GB is cached**. At some point I tried to use a 12GB server instead. Did not work, I had trouble staying in sync.

to understand where RPCDaemon wasted RAM can do:
add flag `--pprof`
`go tool pprof -inuse_space -png http://127.0.0.1:6060/debug/pprof/heap > mem.png`
show this file
also post some logs when you see much RAM to understand what erigon doing in this time

> > I run other things in the server.
> 
> I assumed that, that's why I wanted to see the top. With used, buffered, cached, free memory, the swap, and the other top RAM consumers of the node. I'm no Erigon developer, but I operate an Erigon node for nearly 2 years now, and one thing I know is that Erigon is **very** reliant on his ability to use a huge amount of cached memory. It's not memory exclusively attributed to the process, from what I understand Erigon is massively using files opened through RAM buffer. Technically, the OS manages that space and _will_ reduce its allocation when needed, but then Erigon will start slowing down, and down, and down. As an example, my production node has 16GB RAM, only 7GB is used (mostly by Erigon) but **more than 8GB is cached**. At some point I tried to use a 12GB server instead. Did not work, I had trouble staying in sync.

That is perfectly fine if it needs this amount of memory but then this should be documented. Currently it is written ```Erigon uses ~4Gb of RAM during genesis sync and ~1Gb during normal work. OS pages cache can utilize unlimited amount of memory.```

What's documented, right in the [System Requirements](https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon#system-requirements) of the README.md, is that you need more than 16GB RAM to run Erigon comfortably.
What you are quoting is extracted from a "Known issue" about `htop` incorrectly reporting resident memory vs OS cache, I would not exactly consider that "documentation", especially given what I told you about the importance of said cache for Erigon.

> What's documented, right in the [System Requirements](https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon#system-requirements) of the README.md, is that you need more than 16GB RAM to run Erigon comfortably.
> What you are quoting is extracted from a "Known issue" about `htop` incorrectly reporting resident memory vs OS cache, I would not exactly consider that "documentation", especially given what I told you about the importance of said cache for Erigon.

Erigon does have 16 Gb available. From the 32 Gb installed, I need about ~10 Gb for other things, thus it leaves about 20Gb for Erigon. It used to run fine, but as I mentioned in the top, since months it started struggling.

By the way, the top output I sent above was customised to include the RSAN (resident anonymous) memory: memory that is private to the process and not shared and managed by the OS as page cache. You are saying this number is wrong?

> By the way, the top output I sent above was customised to include the RSAN (resident anonymous) memory: memory that is private to the process and not shared and managed by the OS as page cache. You are saying this number is wrong?

I honestly don't know. I was just referring to the known issue suggesting `htop` reports incorrect numbers but I never dug the subject myself.

> Server load average hovers around 1.5 - 2 for a quad-cpu server. CPU definitely is not a bottleneck.

Erigon is mono-threaded for executions (maybe other stages too, see [there](https://github.com/ledgerwatch/erigon/blob/devel/eth/stagedsync/README.md#stage-6-execute-blocks-stage)), meaning it can only use a single CPU for these phases, so you cannot completely rule out CPU bottleneck from your observation of your server load => maybe that "1" CPU occupied in your 1.5-2 range is actually Erigon struggling to keep up with executions (or another mono-threaded task, idk). I guess you are not a system programmer then. But FYI, a single thread cannot "magically" benefits from having multiple CPUs. Programs must be created in specific way to deal with concurrency of multiple threads. Erigon is a multi-threaded program, don't get me wrong, but the execution stage (for example) is mono-threaded, meaning it only runs in one thread, thus using only one CPU.
Therefore, you can have a CPU bottleneck on executions while observing a 25% load on a quad-core server or 12.5% load on an octocore or a 1% load on a 128 cores server. Doesn't matter how many you have, it only uses one.
